metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Prone Positioning for Patients Intubated for Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) Secondary to COVID-19: observational cohort study Prone Positioning for Patients Intubated for Severe Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) Secondary to COVID-19: observational cohort study

abstract.text: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
• The role of prone positioning in intubated subjects with ARDS secondary to remains unclear.
• The authors report an observational cohort single-centre study of intubated subjects.
• The primary outcome was PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio after initial proning.

• After the initial proning session, improved oxygenation was evident in subjects who survived to discharge following repeated prone positioning. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Background: The role of prone positioning in intubated subjects with acute respiratory distress syndrome caused by coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) remains unclear.
We conducted an observational cohort study of intubated patients admitted to our academic medical centre intensive care unit with COVID-19 between March 18-31 2020.

Exclusion criteria were pregnancy, reintubation and previous prone positioning at a referring hospital. Patients that were placed in the prone position were followed up until hospital discharge. The primary outcome was oxygenation assessed by arterial oxygen tension/fraction of inspired oxygen ratio (PaO 2 /F I O 2 ). Secondary outcomes included PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio improvement ≥20%. Treatment failure of prone positioning was defined as death or requirement for extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO).
Results: Forty-two subjects (29 males; mean age:58.5 [12.7] years) were eligible for analysis.

Nine subjects were placed in the prone position only once, with 25 requiring prone positioning on ≥3 occasions. 31/42 (74%) subjects survived to discharge, with 5 requiring ECMO; 11/42 (26.2%) subjects died. Following the first prone positioning session, mean (SD) PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio increased from 17.9kPa (7.2) to 28.2kPa (12.2) (p<0.01). With repeated prone positioning sessions, 31/42 (73.8%) subjects who were discharged from hospital had PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio improvement of ≥20%, compared to 11/42 subjects who either died or required ECMO (odds ratio:XX (95% confidence intervals:xx-xx)).

Patients with COVID-19 ARDS frequently responded to initial prone positioning with improved oxygenation. Subsequent prone positioning in subjects discharged from hospital was associated with greater improvements in oxygenation. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f 4 Ethical approval: This study was approved by the institutional review board (approval No. 20041301-IRB01). J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f IBW, ideal body weight; BMI, body mass index; COPD, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; Vt, tidal volume; PEEP, positive end expiratory pressure; PaO 2 , arterial oxygen tension; F I O 2 , fraction of inspired oxygen; Cst, static compliance; CK-MB, creatine kinase myocardial band; CRP, C-reactive protein; LDH, lactate dehydrogenase; ECMO, extracorporeal membrane oxygenation; SOFA, sequential organ failure assessment. J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f HR, heart rate; RR, respiratory rate; SBP, systolic blood pressure; DBP, diastolic blood pressure; PEEP, positive end expiratory pressure; PaO 2 , arterial oxygen tension; F I O 2 , fraction of inspired oxygen; PF, PaO 2 /F I O 2 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) is a global pandemic that has affected over 200 countries and territories worldwide. According to the World Health Organization, as of September 12 th , 2020, more than 28 million COVID-19 cases have been reported worldwide, resulting in more than 0.9 million deaths. 1 COVID-19 causes acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) in approximately 20% of hospitalised subjects with COVID-19. 2,3 ARDS has a high mortality rate (35-46%), particularly in subjects with a greater degree of lung injury. 4 As of May 15 th , 2020, 57% of the 4,855 UK hospitalised subjects with COVID-19 that required advanced respiratory support died. 5 Currently, the most effective treatment for COVID-19 is unknown, and management is largely supportive. One treatment recommended by the Surviving Sepsis Campaign (SSC) COVID-19 subcommittee is prone positioning. 6 Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic, studies have shown that early prone positioning can improve the ratio of arterial oxygen tension to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio) and reduce 28-day and 90-day mortality in severe ARDS. [7] [8] [9] Although initial prone positioning improves oxygenation in both non-intubated [10] [11] [12] [13] [14] and intubated [15] [16] [17] patients with COVID-19, the physiological response to repeated prone positioning and its' association with length of stay and mortality for COVID-19 has not been reported.

To prepare for the COVID-19 pandemic, we developed a treatment guideline and standardised approach to initiate prone positioning based on our previous research 18 and input from an interdisciplinary team of respiratory therapists, nurses, and physicians. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of prone positioning for patients with COVID-19 ARDS that required invasive mechanical ventilation.
J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
This observational cohort study was approved by the institutional review board (approval No.

Adult subjects admitted to any of the adult ICUs at our facility with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 infection requiring invasive mechanical ventilation with prone positioning between Mar 18 th and March 31 st , 2020 were included in this study. COVID-19 was confirmed by a positive result on a reverse-transcriptase-polymerase-chain-reaction (RT-PCR) assay of a specimen collected on a nasopharyngeal swab.

Individuals were exclude if they were: 1) pregnant; 2) intubated and placed in the prone positioning at least once at an outside hospital; 3) reintubated and placed in the prone positioning on their second intubation during hospitalisation.

A checklist with an accompanying education video was created to assure consistent prone positioning (supplemental file 1). 19 Considering the volume of subjects that required prone positioning, a multidisciplinary team led by a respiratory therapist was ultimately established to complete all prone and supine sessions. The team was trained using standardised subjects to simulate a patient that was intubated. 18, 19 A treatment guideline was established (supplemental J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f file 2), based on the PROSEVA study 6 length of stay in ICU and hospital were collected. Each patient was followed until hospital discharge.

The primary outcome was oxygenation, assessed by the PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio, before and after the initial prone positioning manoevure. A positive response was prospectively defined as improvement of PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio of ≥ 20%.
We assessed the following secondary outcomes:

1. Serial PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratios were assessed after repeated prone positioning, compared between subjects discharged to home or long-term care facility versus those who died or required ECMO. were intubated and admitted to intensive care. Eight subjects were excluded for not meeting the criteria for prone positioning (n=6), being placed in the prone positioning after reintubation (n=1), or being intubated and placed in prone positioning at an outside hospital for > 24h (n=1).

Of the forty-two subjects eligible for analysis (Table 1 ), 26 were intubated at our institution due to refractory hypoxemia; 16 subjects were intubated elsewhere before transfer to our institution. (Table 2) .
Serial PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratios following repeated prone positioning sessions.

Twenty-five subjects were placed in prone positioning ≥ 3 times. Similar changes in J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f arterial blood gases were observed for the first three prone positioning sessions, although the reduction in F I O 2 was larger after the first prone positioning session than subsequent sessions (Table 3) .

Tidal volume, PEEP, plateau pressure (Table 2) and respiratory system static compliance ( Figure   1 ) were similar throughout repeated prone positioning manoevures. Both set and measured respiratory rates were increased after prone positioning (p<0.01). The ventilatory ratio also improved after prone positioning (Tables 2, 3) .

Vasopressor requirements did not alter after prone positioning, although the propofol dose decreased after the first prone positioning session (Supplemental Table 1 ). Laboratory test results were similar throughout (Supplemental Table 2 ).
After the initial prone positioning session, more subjects who were discharged from hospital had J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f
body_text.section: Oxygenation after prone positioning and outcome.

body_text.text: We found that in COVID-19 subjects placed in prone positioning, oxygenation improved and better oxygenation responses were associated with overall better outcomes. This is the first report to our knowledge on changes in PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio after repeated prone positioning sessions and the associated outcomes of those changes. Although high mortality from severe COVID-19 has been reported, 5, 21-23 our 28 day ICU mortality was 21.4%, which is similar to the PROSEVA study. In PROSERVA, 62.4% of subjects had ARDS due to pneumonia, 6 while all of our subjects had virus-induced ARDS. The pre-prone positioning PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio in our study was higher than that in the PROSEVA study, possibly due to the higher level of PEEP we utilised. If the five subjects we placed on ECMO were grouped with those that died, to simulate the incidence of ECMO utilisation in Italy during the pandemic (1%), 24 our mortality rate (38.1%, 16/42) is still lower than reported mortality for intubated COVID-19 subjects with severe ARDS. 5, [21] [22] [23] Similar to the findings from other studies, 11-13,15-17 PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratios improved after the first prone positioning session in our study, as also reported by Meenen and colleagues. 25 Nevertheless, our study also showed that survivors responded to prone positioning on the second and third prone positioning cycles, in contrast to little or no response in those who ended up being placed on ECMO or those that died. Our findings suggest that the oxygenation response to prone positioning, after each cycle, may be helpful in guiding decisions regarding facility transfer or earlier escalation to ECMO. COVID-19 ARDS has been proposed to be an atypical form of ARDS in terms of recruitability. 26 Gattinoni et al indicated that intubated COVID-19 subjects whose respiratory system compliance was high [50.2 (14.3) ml/cmH 2 O] had lower recruitability, 27 which was J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f consistent with two other European reports. 17, 27 In our study, however, the respiratory system compliance was lower (median:29.2ml/cmH 2 O) than that reported by Gattinoni et al, 17, 27, 28 but similar to four other studies. 15, 16, 22, 29 Additionally, in subjects who responded to prone positioning (defined as PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio improvement of ≥ 20%), we found no difference in preprone positioning respiratory system compliance when compared to non-respondents during the first three prone positioning sessions. The same result was found between the treatment success and treatment failure groups. It should be noted that body mass index was ~1.3 times larger in our study compared to body mass index in the European ARDS population reported by APRONET and others. 8, 28 This might explain low compliance found in our subjects. A trend of higher BMI was seen in the treatment success group, which may reflect the obesity survival paradox described in pneumonia. Future studies are needed to validate this finding in subjects with COVID-19. 30 In our study, we used ventilatory ratio to evaluate dead space. 29, 31 The pre-prone positioning ventilatory ratio in our subjects was higher than the subjects in a preceding study which used similar volume settings. 15 This might be explained by the higher acuity of subjects in our study, as evidenced by the need for higher PEEP, higher plateau pressures, lower compliance, and lower PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratios before initial prone positioning. After prone positioning, the ventilatory ratios were increased within 1 hour. This might be explained by alveolar overdistention caused by the same (pre-prone positioning) PEEP being applied during post-prone positioning. PEEP was reduced around 4 hours after prone positioning in our study, due to the improvement of oxygenation. It was also maintained at that level after supine position, and interestingly, ventilatory ratios returned to pre-prone positioning levels. This finding is J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f suggestive that close monitoring of changes in dead space and timely reduction in PEEP during prone positioning is needed, which might help to avoid alveolar over-distention.

A limitation of this single-centre study was that we did not transport subjects to CT scan to investigate pulmonary morphology that might explain why some subjects did not respond to being placed in the prone positioning. Second, we used ventilatory ratio as a surrogate assessment of dead space. 29 Future studies are needed to understand if ventilatory ratio is an acceptable way to approximate dead space in subjects with COVID-19. 28 Lastly, some data were missing, due to the immediate need for prone positioning and increased staff workload.

FIGREF0.text: and consensus among physician, nursing, and respiratory care leadership at our institution. Intubated subjects diagnosed with ARDS were placed in prone positioning by the team when a patient had a PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio of < 20 kPa with positive end expiratory pressure (PEEP) set ≥ 10 cm H 2 O and F I O 2 ≥ 0.6. prone positioning was maintained for at least 16 hours, except if cardiopulmonary resuscitation was needed. Prone positioning was terminated when PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio remained >20 kPa in the supine position or if extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or palliative care was needed. Lung protective ventilation (tidal volume targeted at 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight, plateau pressure ≤ 30 cm H 2 O, and ARDS network high-PEEP low-F I O 2 tables) 20 were utilised for all subjects. ECMO was considered if oxygenation could not be maintained under lung protective ventilation with prone positioning, paralysis, and inhaled pulmonary vasodilators. Data collection Subject characteristics including age, sex, race, laboratory results, microbiology findings, and diagnosis was collected. COVID-19 epidemiological risk factors including age, pre-existing pulmonary disease, chronic kidney disease, diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, and immunosuppression were also assessed. Pre-and post-prone positioning changes in vital signs, arterial blood gases, ventilator settings, and respiratory mechanics for the first three prone positioning sessions (if applicable) for each individual were recorded. Laboratory tests included creatine kinase myocardial band (CK-MB), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), C-reactive protein (CRP), D-dimer, troponin, ferritin, and absolute lymphocyte within 24 to 48 hours of pre-and post-prone positioning for the first prone positioning session. Use of sedatives and paralytics was also recorded pre-and post-the first prone positioning session. Patient outcomes, including J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f mechanical ventilation duration, successful extubation, escalation of care to ECMO, survival,

FIGREF1.text: Continuous variables were expressed as mean (standard deviation [SD]) or median (Inter-Quartile Range [IQR]), depending on the normality of distribution; the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test was used to test normality of distribution for considered variables. Continuous variables were compared pre-and post-prone positioning by paired t test or Wilcoxon sign rank for the same prone positioning session. Oxygenation before versus post-prone positioning in each session for the first three prone positioning sessions were compared by repeated measures 18 th and March 31 st 2020, 50 subjects with laboratory confirmed COVID-19

FIGREF2.text: prone positioning on at least 3 occasions. No major complications, including pneumothorax were observed. 31/42 (73.8%) subjects survived to discharge (Figure 2), requiring intensive care for 21.5 days (14.8-31.5). Five subjects were placed on ECMO. 11 subjects died, of whom 9 died within 28 days of ICU admission (SupplementalTables 3 and 4).

FIGREF3.text: Primary outcome: oxygenation after initial prone positioning. The PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio improved from 17.9 [7.2] to 28.2 [12.2] kPa within 81 (61-119) minutes of prone positioning in 36 subjects who had complete arterial blood gas data (p<0.01). The PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio improved≥ 20% in 26/36 (72.2%) subjects. After being returned to the supine position, improvements in PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio persisted

FIGREF4.text: F I O 2 ratio improvement of ≥ 20% compared with those requiring ECMO or who died after both the second (STATE NUMBERS AND ODDS RATIO;) and third (STATE NUMBERS AND ODDS RATIO) prone positioning sessions, respectively. In the logistic regression analysis, PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio incremental change in the second prone positioning session was associated with treatment success (odds ratio=1.03, 95% confidence interval [CI] = 1.0-1.05, p=0.03).

FIGREF5.text: In summary, prone positioning improved oxygenation for patient with COVID-19 ARDS that required invasive mechanical ventilation. Serial assessment of the PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratio may help guide decisions for earlier escalation of treatment, including ECMO.

FIGREF7.text: Respiratory system compliance and prone positioning.Using the changes of PaO 2 /F I O 2 ratios pre and post prone positioning > 20% as the response criteria, 26 subjects met the criteria in the first prone positioning session (n=36) while 13 and 11 subjects responded in the second (n=27) and third (n=20) prone positioning sessions, respectively. Respondents' respiratory system compliance before each prone positioning in the three sessions was similar to non-respondents.Cst, compliance of respiratory system.
